Vol. XXXV, No. 2

AGREEMENT MADE
AT BOARD MEETING
Second Term Rushing is to Be
Inaugurated This
Year
VOTE IS 12-2
Culmination of Movement Agitated Last Spring
Corning as a result of a movement started last spring by the
Dean and the Committee on Student
Affairs, the Interfraternity Board
yesterday voted to inaugurate second semester rushing this year
instead of the old system of six
weeks rushing at the beginning of
the year followed immediately by
the pledging of the new men. It
was felt that by postponing the
rushing of a man until after he had
successfully passed his mid-year
exams that he would have a chance
to show just what he was capable
of doing and that he was in college
for work and not merely for a nice
loafing time. Furthermore, the fraternities would have a better chance
to see the new men under all conditions and would have a longer
time to look him over and decide
Whether he would make a good fraternity man; the rushee, on the
other hand, would be better able to
look the different fraternities over
and to decide which bid he would
accept (provided, of course, that he
got more than one bid).

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 7,1930

SENIORS SCHEDULE
MEETING THURSDAY
A meeting of the Senior
class will be held next Thursday at 12:20 in room 120 in
the C. E. Building. Eddie
Lockhard, the retiring president, will take charge of the
meeting. Nominations for all
the class offices to be filled will
be made and it is hoped by the
president that a representative
number of the senior class
will be present so that the
business can be successfully
carried on.

HOPKINS HAS NIGHT-CLUB WITHOUT
GIN, GINGER ALE, TIGHTS OR DRAWERS

heard of night clubs in attics. You
have heard of pseudo-night clubs
even in church vestry rooms where
gin was supplanted by ginger ale
and tights have given away to long
drawers. And then you hear of
Hopkins' (own) Iddins-Van Orman coup. Hopkins' (own) IddinsVan Orman duo has a night club
without gin, ginger ale, tights or
long drawers. They play football.
And though they have no gin,
ginger ale, tights or long drawers,
and though it is thoroughly,
thoroughly, thoroughly incidental,
Hopkins'(own) Iddins-Van Orman
make money.
And you, being a metriculous
person, wonder how the lighted
football field business began. And
if it began—like the flag in the flag
story—something like this:
Quarterback: Captain, we ain't
got no lights on our football field!
Captain: What? V‘Te ain't got no
lights on our football field! I gotta
go tell the coach!
Captain: Coach, we ain't got no
lights on our football field!
Coach: What? We ain't got no
lights on our football field! I gotta
go tell my pal Iddins!
Coach: Mr. Iddins, we ain't got
no lights on our football field!
Iddins: 'What? We ain't got no
lights on our football field!
Coach: No, we ain't got no lights
on our football field!

But you are not sure. And you
also wonder why Hopkins' (own)
Iddins-Van Orman duo started their
night club. And you think awhile
and wonder if it was because they
are romantic. You think awhile
and think yes, Iddins and Van Orman must be romantic. For you
know that half the football teams
help build half of the college buildings. And that, according to the
Carnegie Foundation is very unromantic.
And you think awhile and figure
that Iddins and his pal Van Orman
figure that the Public figures that
football is on a par with—for illustrative purposes—hot dog vending. And that they, under the romance of the stars, want to put it
on a par with—for illustrative purposes—minature golf and necking.
But you wonder what the football
players are going to do about it.
They play in the afternoon. They
play at night. And they have no
time to drink. If they can't drink
in the afternoon, how are they going to play at night? If they don't
drink at . night, how are they going
to play in the afternoon? You knew
that last year's team needed efficiency, but they needed good gin
more than they needed efficiency.
And you wonder. But you are
sure of one thing. You are sure
that Iddins and his pal Van Orman
are romantic.

OPERATOR REDUCED TO SKELETON BY
RIGORS OF DIALING; TO ABDICATE once in her career has she given a
Dial phones claim another victim.
Siding with Governmental officials,
the Hopkins switchboard manipulator has registered her disapproval
of this modern contrivance which
reduces a perfect figure to that of
a skeleton.
As one enters her room, one immediately sees two dirty, halfopened windows, which have been
in this condition since the cornerstone to Gilman Hall was laid. On
the left one sees a row of dingy,
dilapidated chest of drawers, containing a compact and powder case
and one cracked mirror. In short,
one would think that he was entering the "House of Usher," except
for the fact the one pair of legs,

neatly encircled by rayon stockings,
two white arms, exposed to the view
of any visitor, and two big brown
eyes greet the casual intruder. This
transports one to a more modern
and rapidly-moving world.
Last year the occupant of the
above described room received the
appointment as chief (and only)
operator of the Hopkins switchboard. After she leaves her beloved
switchboard she will enter one of
Baltimore's secretarial schools in an
attempt to add stenographic knowledge to her present telephonic abilities. She plans, after six months
of this training, to obtain a position
of less work, worry and wages.
The subject of discussion possesses

wrong number; she called her boyfriend instead of the fire department (hot stuff!) when the chemistry laboratory was on fire.
After the twenty-fifth of this
month, when Miss Operator leaves,
the attendance in the library and
punctuality at lectures, will, no
doubt, increase.
Although there is a Private, No
Admittance sign on the door of the
telephone room, Freshmen as well
as upper classmen soon find out
that "Fools walk in where angels
fear to tread." But how swell it
must be to be a fool!

EDITORIALS
NIGHT FOOTBALL AND THE FUTURE

ONE

football has been introduced to Hopkins students. The
NIGHT
initial performance at Homewood was not a roaring success. The
gate was rather poor. The old thrill was absent. What should have
been an occasion for much rejoicing turned out to be a rather dull affair.
There were numerous complaints. Some objected to the cold, others to
the lights, which they claimed hurt their eyes. We may be taught to
like night football but the process of learning is rather unpleasant.
As to the game itself, it was an unqualified success. Brighter days
ahead in the athletic world may be seen for Hopkins. Sports writers
of the Baltimore daily papers pointed out that we would have to wait
another week before judging the strength of the Hopkins team. However, we know Upsala to be of _approximately the same calibre as the
Juniata team which defeated Hopkins in the opening home game last
season. We do not predict anything so rash as an undefeated season,
but the Hopkins team has a score punch. Future games will be worth
watching. The team appeared to be well coached and in excellent
condition. There was not a single senior in the starting line-up. Most
of the reserves were freshmen. We hope that Hopkins is entering a
new athletic era.

We firmly advocate the playing of the Lehigh and Haverford games
in the afternoon. Both of these games should draw a large crowd to
Homewood. Judging from the attendance at the opening game, it
is doubtful that the playing of either game at night will draw any
larger crowd that would the same game in the afternoon. On the
other hand, it is certain that football in the sunlight has a much;
greater appeal for Hopkins students. We regret that Hopkins is forced
to play St. John's at night due to the shifting of the Navy-Southern
Methodist game from Annapolis to the Stadium.

THE STUDENT COUNCIL
TT seems to us quiet regretable that the administration was forced to
eject the principal organ of student government at Hopkins from its
office. It is no doubt true that the Student Council does not need a
room all the time throughout the year. On certain occasions, nevertheless, it is imperative that this body have a room to carry on their
work, and furthermore they cannot share this room with anyone else.
There work has to be done in private. Let us hope that the administration is able to find another location for the governing body of the
student government of which the University is proud.

TO THE FRESHMEN
RESHMAN regulations have been completely abolished at Hopkins.
FSome
traditions remain however. One of these is not observed as
well as it might be. We refer to the custom of speaking to every
Hopkins man met on the campus. This seems at first sight to be a
rather trivial thing. "Hello," however, creates a friendly spirit much
to be desired. Some of the present freshman class seem to realize it,
others either do not care or have attempted it, and not receiving any
reply have ceased the practice. We merely ask the freshman to remember that he is expected to speak first, and to notice that he will
be answered except in rare cases.

DORM DOINGS
The men are all back in the dorm,
augmented by many quaint and
atrocious specimens of Freshmen.
Most of the rooms are occupied.
However, there are several vacancies—the food is as good a
reason as yours.
For a short time gloom hovered
over the denizens of the dorm. But
it has since been dispelled by clouds
of smoke arising from the many
"bull-sessions."
There is a peculiar odor pervading the environs of the third hall
of "B"—That reminds us, "The
Yudkin" (pugly-ugly) has returned
in all his Freshman glory.
Poker games and dancing classes
are again in full swing with the aid
of, respectively, cards and a victrola.
And, oh, those Freshman colors,
pink, orange, green and yellow,
from which the lowly ones derive
so much pleasure!

Levering Hall seems to have become the place of study for the
frosh. Evidently the chairs are
comfortable, music enchanting and,
boy, that feminine environment.
Those "nite-birds" seem to be
having one deuce of a good time—
these Baltimore women must be
quite charming.
Getting is back at the old
"grind." Perhaps he is thinking of
his "girl," but we doubt it. Study
improves the mind.
Some brilliant math prof. decided that for the first day's work
in Trig it would do no harm to give
one-quarter of the book for the advancement of education of "thosetoo-lazy-to-work."
Miniature golf has made an impression, or rather, a dent among
our swelling ranks.
Jesse Robinson, the man with the
line from Yonkers, is occupying
"Big" Robinson's shoes. It's a
pleasure observing him play minature golf on a five-foot course, and

Over 30 New Men Turn Out
For Initial Meeting
Thirty new candidates for the
Black and Blue Jay who attended a
meeting of the staff and candidates,
held last Friday, October 3, in the
Jay offices, give promise of a successful year for the Hopkins magazine of wit and humor. Harold
Bloom, the editor-in-chief, presided
over the meeting and welcomed the
new men.
Bloom announced that the first
issue of the Black and Blue Jay
would appear on Tuesday, October
7. It is expected that this issue will
create quite a surprise on the
campus. The art staff has designed
a new cover that is expected to be
a considerable improvement over
last year's attractive one, and several features will make their appearance in new and enlarged
forms.
A monthly theatre article, much
desired by the theatre-goers, will
announce advance news of local
motion pictures and stage productions. It will be different from
"Seen in the Pit" of last year, and
will not be critical in treatment.
"Around the Campus," a feature
of humorous comment, will be expanded this year, and a sport page
will comment on undergraduate
athletics.
Candidates for the staff are
urgently requested to turn in their
names at the office of the Black and
Blue Jay. People with any sort of
artistic ability are especially requested to apply, and all will be
given a chance to show their worth.
"Those who do not know how to
draw will be taught to do so," said
Harold Bloom, "and all will have
a good opportunity to learn the fine
points of cartooning and other art
work."

ANNIVERSARY

A

123,000 tests a year
In the Crane testing laboratories, the
weight arm of a specially designed machine measures the steadily increasing
load suspended from a small cylinder of
metal. Watching it intently is a man who
has at his command instruments that
measure to .0000s of an inch. The cylinder begins to yield; he notes the weight.
It snaps; he notes the weight. Disengaging it, he measures the stretch and
diameter at the breaking point. These
tests form a part of the 123,000 determinations Crane Co. makes on its own materials every year.
63,000 of the tests are chemical; not one
component from pig iron to limestone
flux is charged in a Crane melting furnace
whose suitability has not been determined
by analysis. 6o,000 are physical; not
one hour's melt is drawn off in a Crane
foundry whose physical properties—tensile, transverse, and torsional strengths,
yield point, breaking point, elongation,
and reduction of area are not known.
By such exhaustive tests and by researches ofscientists in Crane laboratories,
a vast body ofauthoritative data on metals
and their properties has been collected.
It is embodied in a book,"Pioneering in
Science," which is an invaluable reference
book for students. On request, we will
send it to you.

Vol. XXXV, No. 2

AGREEMENT MADE
AT BOARD MEETING
Second Term Rushing is to Be
Inaugurated This
Year
VOTE IS 12-2
Culmination of Movement Agitated Last Spring
Corning as a result of a movement started last spring by the
Dean and the Committee on Student
Affairs, the Interfraternity Board
yesterday voted to inaugurate second semester rushing this year
instead of the old system of six
weeks rushing at the beginning of
the year followed immediately by
the pledging of the new men. It
was felt that by postponing the
rushing of a man until after he had
successfully passed his mid-year
exams that he would have a chance
to show just what he was capable
of doing and that he was in college
for work and not merely for a nice
loafing time. Furthermore, the fraternities would have a better chance
to see the new men under all conditions and would have a longer
time to look him over and decide
Whether he would make a good fraternity man; the rushee, on the
other hand, would be better able to
look the different fraternities over
and to decide which bid he would
accept (provided, of course, that he
got more than one bid).

OPERATOR REDUCED TO SKELETON BY
RIGORS OF DIALING; TO ABDICATE once in her career has she given a
Dial phones claim another victim.
Siding with Governmental officials,
the Hopkins switchboard manipulator has registered her disapproval
of this modern contrivance which
reduces a perfect figure to that of
a skeleton.
As one enters her room, one immediately sees two dirty, halfopened windows, which have been
in this condition since the cornerstone to Gilman Hall was laid. On
the left one sees a row of dingy,
dilapidated chest of drawers, containing a compact and powder case
and one cracked mirror. In short,
one would think that he was entering the "House of Usher," except
for the fact the one pair of legs,

neatly encircled by rayon stockings,
two white arms, exposed to the view
of any visitor, and two big brown
eyes greet the casual intruder. This
transports one to a more modern
and rapidly-moving world.
Last year the occupant of the
above described room received the
appointment as chief (and only)
operator of the Hopkins switchboard. After she leaves her beloved
switchboard she will enter one of
Baltimore's secretarial schools in an
attempt to add stenographic knowledge to her present telephonic abilities. She plans, after six months
of this training, to obtain a position
of less work, worry and wages.

EDITORIALS
NIGHT FOOTBALL AND THE FUTURE

ONE

football has been introduced to Hopkins students. The
NIGHT
initial performance at Homewood was not a roaring success. The
gate was rather poor. The old thrill was absent. What should have
been an occasion for much rejoicing turned out to be a rather dull affair.
There were numerous complaints. Some objected to the cold, others to
the lights, which they claimed hurt their eyes. We may be taught to
like night football but the process of learning is rather unpleasant.
As to the game itself, it was an unqualified success. Brighter days
ahead in the athletic world may be seen for Hopkins. Sports writers
of the Baltimore daily papers pointed out that we would have to wait
another week before judging the strength of the Hopkins team. However, we know Upsala to be of _approximately the same calibre as the
Juniata team which defeated Hopkins in the opening home game last
season. We do not predict anything so rash as an undefeated season,
but the Hopkins team has a score punch. Future games will be worth
watching. The team appeared to be well coached and in excellent
condition. There was not a single senior in the starting line-up. Most
of the reserves were freshmen. We hope that Hopkins is entering a
new athletic era.

Likewise what counts in a cigarette is what a smoker gets from
it — not what is said about it.
Chesterfield has a policy—give

We firmly advocate the playing of the Lehigh and Haverford games
in the afternoon. Both of these games should draw a large crowd to
Homewood. Judging from the attendance at the opening game, it
is doubtful that the playing of either game at night will draw any
larger crowd that would the same game in the afternoon. On the
other hand, it is certain that football in the sunlight has a much;
greater appeal for Hopkins students. We regret that Hopkins is forced
to play St. John's at night due to the shifting of the Navy-Southern
Methodist game from Annapolis to the Stadium.

THE STUDENT COUNCIL
TT seems to us quiet regretable that the administration was forced to
eject the principal organ of student government at Hopkins from its
office. It is no doubt true that the Student Council does not need a
room all the time throughout the year. On certain occasions, nevertheless, it is imperative that this body have a room to carry on their
work, and furthermore they cannot share this room with anyone else.
There work has to be done in private. Let us hope that the administration is able to find another location for the governing body of the
student government of which the University is proud.

TO THE FRESHMEN
RESHMAN regulations have been completely abolished at Hopkins.
FSome
traditions remain however. One of these is not observed as
well as it might be. We refer to the custom of speaking to every
Hopkins man met on the campus. This seems at first sight to be a
rather trivial thing. "Hello," however, creates a friendly spirit much
to be desired. Some of the present freshman class seem to realize it,
others either do not care or have attempted it, and not receiving any
reply have ceased the practice. We merely ask the freshman to remember that he is expected to speak first, and to notice that he will
be answered except in rare cases.

DORM DOINGS
The men are all back in the dorm,
augmented by many quaint and
atrocious specimens of Freshmen.
Most of the rooms are occupied.
However, there are several vacancies—the food is as good a
reason as yours.
For a short time gloom hovered
over the denizens of the dorm. But
it has since been dispelled by clouds
of smoke arising from the many
"bull-sessions."
There is a peculiar odor pervading the environs of the third hall
of "B"—That reminds us, "The
Yudkin" (pugly-ugly) has returned
in all his Freshman glory.
Poker games and dancing classes
are again in full swing with the aid
of, respectively, cards and a victrola.
And, oh, those Freshman colors,
pink, orange, green and yellow,
from which the lowly ones derive
so much pleasure!

Levering Hall seems to have become the place of study for the
frosh. Evidently the chairs are
comfortable, music enchanting and,
boy, that feminine environment.
Those "nite-birds" seem to be
having one deuce of a good time—
these Baltimore women must be
quite charming.
Getting is back at the old
"grind." Perhaps he is thinking of
his "girl," but we doubt it. Study
improves the mind.
Some brilliant math prof. decided that for the first day's work
in Trig it would do no harm to give
one-quarter of the book for the advancement of education of "thosetoo-lazy-to-work."
Miniature golf has made an impression, or rather, a dent among
our swelling ranks.
Jesse Robinson, the man with the
line from Yonkers, is occupying
"Big" Robinson's shoes. It's a
pleasure observing him play minature golf on a five-foot course, and
hit the ball on its head until it's
dead, dead, dead

Over 30 New Men Turn Out
For Initial Meeting
Thirty new candidates for the
Black and Blue Jay who attended a
meeting of the staff and candidates,
held last Friday, October 3, in the
Jay offices, give promise of a successful year for the Hopkins magazine of wit and humor. Harold
Bloom, the editor-in-chief, presided
over the meeting and welcomed the
new men.
Bloom announced that the first
issue of the Black and Blue Jay
would appear on Tuesday, October
7. It is expected that this issue will
create quite a surprise on the
campus. The art staff has designed
a new cover that is expected to be
a considerable improvement over
last year's attractive one, and several features will make their appearance in new and enlarged
forms.
A monthly theatre article, much
desired by the theatre-goers, will
announce advance news of local
motion pictures and stage productions. It will be different from
"Seen in the Pit" of last year, and
will not be critical in treatment.
"Around the Campus," a feature
of humorous comment, will be expanded this year, and a sport page
will comment on undergraduate
athletics.
Candidates for the staff are
urgently requested to turn in their
names at the office of the Black and
Blue Jay. People with any sort of
artistic ability are especially requested to apply, and all will be
given a chance to show their worth.

ANNIVERSARY

A

123,000 tests a year
In the Crane testing laboratories, the
weight arm of a specially designed machine measures the steadily increasing
load suspended from a small cylinder of
metal. Watching it intently is a man who
has at his command instruments that
measure to .0000s of an inch. The cylinder begins to yield; he notes the weight.
It snaps; he notes the weight. Disengaging it, he measures the stretch and
diameter at the breaking point. These
tests form a part of the 123,000 determinations Crane Co. makes on its own materials every year.
63,000 of the tests are chemical; not one
component from pig iron to limestone
flux is charged in a Crane melting furnace
whose suitability has not been determined
by analysis. 6o,000 are physical; not
one hour's melt is drawn off in a Crane
foundry whose physical properties—tensile, transverse, and torsional strengths,
yield point, breaking point, elongation,
and reduction of area are not known.
By such exhaustive tests and by researches ofscientists in Crane laboratories,
a vast body ofauthoritative data on metals
and their properties has been collected.
It is embodied in a book,"Pioneering in
Science," which is an invaluable reference
book for students. On request, we will
send it to you.
